Award.AwardTitle: FIA-NP: Collaborative Research: Named Data Networking Next Phase (NDN-NP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Named Data Networking (NDN) is a Future Internet Architecture inspired by years of empirical research into network usage and a growing awareness of unsolved problems in IP. Its premise is that the Internet is primarily used as an information distribution network, which is not a good match for IP, and that the future Internet's "thin waist" should be based on named data rather than numerically addressed hosts. This proposal continues research started in 2010 under NSF's FIA program. It applies the principal investigators' (PIs) increasing understanding of NDN opportunities and challenges to two national priorities--Health IT and Cyber-physical Systems--to further evolve the architecture in the experimental manner that has proven successful. The research agenda is organized to translate key results in architecture and security into library code that guides application development towards native NDN designs. It simultaneously continues fundamental research into the challenges of global scalability and opportunities for innovation created by "simply" routing and forwarding data based on names.

The NDN research agenda includes: 1) Applications--exploring naming and application design patterns; rendezvous, discovery and bootstrapping; the design of in-network storage; and use of new synchronization primitives; 2) Security & trustworthiness--providing basic building blocks of key management, trust management, and encryption-based access control, and anticipating future security challenges; 3) Routing and forwarding strategy--developing and evaluating path-vector, link-state, and hyperbolic options for inter-domain routing, addressing routing security and trust, and designing fast forwarding and mobility support; 4) Scalable forwarding--aiming to support real-world deployment, evaluation and adoption via an operational, scalable forwarding platform; 5) Libraries & tools--developing reference implementations based on the team's fundamental results; 6) Social & economic impacts--considering specific questions of the target environments and broader ones arising in a "World on NDN." The PIs choose Mobile Health and Enterprise Building Automation & Management Systems as specific environments to validate the architecture and drive new research. Domain experts will be 1) Open mHealth, a non-profit patient-centric ecosystem led by Deborah Estrin (Cornell) and Ida Sim (UCSF); and 2) UCLA Facilities Management, operators of the second largest Siemens building monitoring system on the West Coast. To guide research on the security dimensions of these environments and NDN more generally, the NDN team has convened a Security Advisory Council to complement its own effort.

Intellectual Merit: NDN builds on lessons learned from the success of IP, preserving the thin waist, hierarchical naming, and end-to-end principles. The design recognizes the major shift in the applications communication model, from the "where" (i.e., the host/location) to the "what" (i.e., the content). Architecting a communications infrastructure around this shift can radically simplify application designs, enabling them to communicate directly using content names they desire and leaving it to the network to figure out how and from where to retrieve it. NDN also recognizes that the biggest weakness in the current Internet architecture is lack of security, and incorporates a fundamental building block to improve security by requiring that all content be signed.

Broader Impacts: The success of new architectures requires community involvement and uptake. NDN has built momentum through a commitment to an open source model that has spurred substantial research activity in both architecture and current implementation. Project members are often invited to present at "future Internet" meetings around the world, and the PIs have performed high-visibility demos of NDN's ability to handle large scale distribution. Industry is also showing increasing participation. Finally, NDN has significantly impacted students, generating several Ph.D. theses, related industry internships, and both graduate and undergraduate classes that can now present a comprehensive alternative to IP to stimulate discussion of what network architecture design really means.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Named Data Networking (NDN) is a Future Internet Architecture inspired by a growing awareness of unsolved problems in IP. Its premise is that the Internet is primarily used as an information distribution network, which is not a good match for IP, and that the future Internet's "thin waist" should be based on named data rather than numerically addressed hosts. NDN also recognizes that the biggest weakness in the current Internet architecture is lack of security, and incorporates a fundamental building block to improve security by requiring that all content be signed.

This project continued research started in 2010 under NSF's FIA program, and focused on exploring name-based application design patterns; providing basic building blocks for security and trustworthiness; improving routing and forwarding strategies and scalable forwarding techniques; developing libraries and tools; and considering social and economic ramifications of NDN.

Research at the University of Michigan concentrated on security aspects of the project, which included several notable outcomes that have improved security both for NDN and for traditional IP-based systems:

  • Certificates and PKI. NDN’s ubiquitous data signing informed the development of the Automated Certificate Management Environment (ACME) protocol, which has since been standardized by the IETF, and an NDN-specific derivate, NDNCERT. These protocols foster simple yet secure automated certificate issuance. ACME was adopted by Let's Encrypt, a non-profit certificate authority, and today helps safeguard over 70 million websites—more than half of all HTTPS-protected sites worldwide. This has helped accelerate global HTTPS deployment, which increased from 45% to 70% of initial connections during the project period.
  • Name-based confidentiality and authentication. Unlike traditional channel-based confidentiality solutions, which only secure data in motion, the name-based access control approach developed under this project retains confidentiality of data at rest, which better facilitates data distribution architectures like NDN. The project also developed a look-back authentication model that allows consumers to check whether signatures were valid at the time they were produced, facilitating a shift from connection-oriented to data-oriented networking.
  • Protecting Internet data transport. Characterizing NDN's security required understanding the baseline security of transport-layer protections used in traditional Internet applications. Studies under this project revealed new vulnerabilities in widely deployed protocols and systems and helped repair them. These included discovery of two major vulnerabilities in TLS (the Logjam and DROWN attacks), which compromised about 20% of HTTPS sites globally; characterization of vulnerabilities in SMTP email delivery, which inspired Gmail to deploy new security indicators; and analysis and monitoring of the catastrophic OpenSSL Heartbleed vulnerability, which contributed to the field's understanding of how to respond to major Internet security breaches. These efforts resulted in widespread security improvements in deployed protocols, browsers, and servers.
  • Emerging threats to the Internet of Things. NDN offers a new approach to securing the Internet of Things, which the project explored with the EBAMS and Open mHealth environments. In order to provide a baseline for IoT security, work under this project also studied the Mirai botnet, a massive network of compromised IoT devices that mounted some of the largest distributed denial-of-service attacks ever observed. This comprehensive analysis of Mirai tracked its growth, evolution, and malicious activity, providing insights about what fueled the problem and pointing to future directions for security and IoT research. The work contributed to the arrest and prosecution of the botnet creator and informed Federal Trade Commission enforcement action against a major global manufacturer of computer networking equipment.
  • Content-based security for today’s web. NDN’s name-based security architecture can be applied to address integrity and confidentiality challenges of the IP-based World Wide Web. Under such a content-based security approach, data is directly signed and encrypted at rest, enabling it to be delivered via any path and then validated by the browser. The NDN team laid out a research agenda to realize this vision.

Work supported under the project appeared at top publication venues, including ACM CCS, ACM IMC, and USENIX Security. These publications were recognized with two Best Paper awards, an IRTF Applied Networking Research Prize, and a DEFCON Pwnie award.

In addition, the project supported the training of several students in computer science, networking, and security. One undergraduate supported under the project completed her degree and went on to a respected Ph.D. program. Three Ph.D. students supported under the project completed degrees and went on to work at a major Internet companies. All of these students were exposed to new security concepts and challenges posed by the NDN architecture, and had an opportunity to interact with project participants from partner institutions.

The overall impact of this project has been to strengthen the security and trustworthiness of the Internet, through development of new network architectures that offer integrated security protections, and through contributions to the field's understanding of the security challenges created by the IP network architecture.
